Basics

print() function:

Show the code 
print('hello world')
hello world
Show the code 
print("welcome to data science")
welcome to data science

Printing Multiple Pieces of Data

Show the code 
print("hell0989")
Show the code 
import datetime # module
Show the code 
Full_Date = datetime.datetime.now() # functions Current date and time
print(Full_Date)
2023-04-11 17:53:53.692570
Show the code 
year = datetime.datetime.now().year # atrribute
month = datetime.datetime.now().month
day = datetime.datetime.now().day
print(year)
print(month)
print(day)
2023
4
11
Show the code 
print("Today's", 'Date', day, month, year)# this will print the value to the output
Today's Date 11 4 2023
Show the code 
print(50, 1000, 3.142, "Hello World") # print can hold different datatypes with comma seperated, output as space seperated each values
50 1000 3.142 Hello World
Show the code 
print("hello world" + "!") #concatenatiing two strings without space
hello world!
Show the code 
print(23+56)
79

By default, each print statement prints text in a new line. If we want multiple print statements to print in the same line, we can use the following code:

Show the code 
print() # in jupyter: shift+tab(4)
Show the code 
print("Hello")
print("World")
######################
Hello
World
Show the code 
print("Hello", end="")
print("World")
######################
HelloWorld
Show the code 
print("Hello", end=" ")
print("World")
Hello World
Show the code 
print("welcome", "to", "python", sep="_", end=";")
print("other sentence")
welcome_to_python;other sentence
Show the code 
print("welcome", "to", "python", sep="_", end=";")  #instead of new line we have been added ;
print("data science") # its by default new line will be the end of this code line
print("technology")
welcome_to_python;data science
technology
Show the code 
print("welcome", "to", "python", sep="_", end="$")
print("data science")
welcome_to_python$data science
Show the code 
print("welcome", "to", "python", sep="_", end="\n") # end with new line(by default)
print("data science")
welcome_to_python
data science

comment with # and ''' symbols:

Single Line Comment:

Show the code 
# this statement will print the value inside in it
print("welcome to data science")
welcome to data science

Multi Line Comment(each line in seperated):

Show the code 
'''hello hai'''
'hello hai'
Show the code 
'''
this statement will print the factorial of the number we
gave from math module
'''
import math # module
math.factorial(5) # printed the factorial of 5 here
120
Show the code 
'''
this statement will print the statement inside in it
we can use print function and write sentense or values
inside within the unction
Other Statement
'''
'\nthis statement will print the statement inside in it\nwe can use print function and write sentense or values\ninside within the unction\nOther Statement\n'
Show the code 
print('''
This value printed
addition of 
two values you gave,
in this case your
current age will be displayed
''')
# print(#this is comment)
prev_age = 23 
years_over = 4
current_age=  prev_age + years_over
print(current_age)

This value printed
addition of 
two values you gave,
in this case your
current age will be displayed

27
Show the code 
'''
this statement will print the statement inside in it
we can use print function and write sentense or values
inside within the unction
Three
'''
print("welcome to data science")
welcome to data science

Taking help: Keywords, Identifiers and modules…etc:

In Python, keywords are predefined and reserved words with specific meanings. The syntax of the coding is defined by keywords. The keyword is not allowed to be used as an identifier, function name, or variable name. Except for True and False, all keywords in Python are written in lower case. Python 3.7 contains 33 keywords; let’s go over them all one by one.

An identifier is a name that is used to identify a variable, function, class, module, and so on. The identifier is a string of characters followed by an underscore. The identifier should begin with a character or an Underscore and end with a digit. The letters are A-Z or a-Z, an underscore (_), and digits (0-9). Special characters (#, @, $,%,!) should not be used in identifiers.

Show the code 
#help()

Welcome to Python 3.10's help utility!

If this is your first time using Python, you should definitely check out
the tutorial on the internet at https://docs.python.org/3.10/tutorial/.

Enter the name of any module, keyword, or topic to get help on writing
Python programs and using Python modules.  To quit this help utility and
return to the interpreter, just type "quit".

To get a list of available modules, keywords, symbols, or topics, type
"modules", "keywords", "symbols", or "topics".  Each module also comes
with a one-line summary of what it does; to list the modules whose name
or summary contain a given string such as "spam", type "modules spam".

Operators

Operators (Decreasing order of precedence) Operators (Decreasing order of precedence)
+, -, *, /, //, % Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication, Division, Floor division, Modulus(reminder)
** Exponent
< > <= >= == != Comparison operators
= %= /= //= -= += *= **= Assignment Operators
is is not Identity operators
in not in Membership operators
not or and Logical operators

Primitive Data Types

Python has many native datatypes. Here are the important ones:

  • Booleans are either True or False.
  • Numbers can be integers (1 and 2), floats like (1.1 and 1.2) or fractions (1/2 and 2/3), or even complex numbers.
  • Strings are sequences of Unicode characters, e.g. an html document.
Show the code 
# Boolean---True/False
# Numbers ---int,float,complex
# Strings---'data' or "python"
# date and time

Booleans

Show the code 
t = True # storing True into an object or variable
Show the code 
type(t)
bool
Show the code 
1 == True
True
Show the code 
abc = False
print(type(abc))
<class 'bool'>
Show the code 
False == 0
True
Show the code 
print(False * 1879878)
print("hello" * 23)
print(23 * 23)
0
hellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohellohello

Number Calculations
(Operator Precedence)

Show the code 
3+3/3 # this will might restult 2, but observe result
Show the code 
(3+3)/3 # here you will get 2 
2.0
Show the code 
((((13+5)*2)-4)/2)-13
# How did that happen? Let’s work it out.
# 13+5 gives us 18
# 18*2 gives us 36
# 36-4 gives us 32
# 32/2 gives us 16.0 #Note that division gives us floats!
# 16-13 gives us 3.0
3.0
Show the code 
# Different precedence
print(10 - 3 * 2)  # Multiplication computed first, followed by subtraction
# Same precedence
print(3 * 20 / 5)  # Multiplication computed first, followed by division
print(3 / 20 * 5)  # Division computed first, followed by multiplication
print(30 + 20 - 5)  # subtraction computed first, then  addition
# Whenever operators have equal precedence, the expression is computed from the left side:
4
12.0
0.75
45
Show the code 
3/60
0.05
Show the code 
13+5*2-4/2-3**2 # Bodmas ()
12.0
Show the code 
num1 = 5
num2 = 10
num3 = 10
list1 = [6,7,8]
list2 = [6,7,8]
Show the code 
print(num2 > num1)  # 10 is greater than 5
True
Show the code 
print(num1 > num2)  # 5 is not greater than 10
False
Show the code 
print(num2 == num3)  # Both have the same value
True
Show the code 
print(num3 != num1)  # Both have different values
True
Show the code 
print(3 + 10 == 5 + 5)  # Both are not equal
False
Show the code 
print(3 >= 2)  # 3 is not less than or equal to 2
True
Show the code 
print(num2 is not num3)  # Both have the same object
num2 = 6
num3 = -8
print(num2 is not num3)
False
True

Show the code 
num1 = 10
num2 = 10
print(num1)
print(num2)
print(num1 is num2)
10
10
True
Show the code 
list1 = [6, 7, 8]
list2 = [6, 7, 8]
print(list1)
print(list2)
print(list1 is list2)  # Both have the different objects
#The == and != operators compare the values of both operands. However, the identity operators, 
# is and is not, check whether the two operands are the exact same object.
[6, 7, 8]
[6, 7, 8]
False
Show the code 
num1 = 10
num2 = 10

print(id(num2))
1442932550224
1442932550224

print(id(list2))
1443017128384
1443017128512

Strings

  • string is a ordered sequence of characters (primitive).
  • A string has to be creaed within two quotes or single quotes also displays as single or double quotes.
  • A string can be spaces or digits.
  • A string can also be special characters.
  • Positive / Negative indexing applicable (positive sarted with 0 and goes on increasing, negative ended wih -1 )
  • Strings are immutable(we cannot change inplace but we can create another string from it)
Show the code 
st = 'data science 1466 and machine learning &^ %% #@! )( with python'
Show the code 
type(st)
str
Show the code 
len(st) # functions
63

The index() method is similar to find() method for strings. The only difference is that find() method returns -1 if the substring is not found, whereas index() throws an exception. find() method also returns not only first matching it also returns other matching letter position/index.

strings immutable nature

Show the code 
# my_string = "abc"
# my_string[0] = "d"
TypeError: 'str' object does not support item assignment

my_string = "abc"
my_string[0] = "d"

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-f26f28798517> in <module>()
      1 my_string = "abc"
----> 2 my_string[0] = "d"

TypeError: 'str' object does not support item assignment

strings are immutable, which means you can’t change an existing string (inplace). The best you can do is create a new string that is a variation on the original:

Show the code 
greeting = 'Hello, world!'
new_greeting = 'J' + greeting[1:]
print(new_greeting)
print(greeting)
Jello, world!
Hello, world!

String.format()

Show the code 
p = 'python'
string1 = "I %s like %s" % (p,"hello") 
print(string1) # 'I like Python'
I python like hello
Show the code 
temp = "Data Science"
string2 = "I like %s" % temp
print(string2) # 'I like Data Science'
# The %s is the format specifier, which tells Python to insert the text here. Python will insert a string if:

string3 = "I like %s and %s" % ("Python", temp)
print(string3)  # 'I like Python and Data Science'
I like Python
I like Data Science
I like Python and Data Science
Show the code 
# Inserting Integers Within a String#
my_string = "%i + %i = %i" % (1,2,3)
print(my_string) # '1 + 2 = 3'

# Inserting Floats Within a String#
string1 = "%f" % (1.11)
print(string1) # '1.110000'

string2 = "%.2f" % (1.11)
print(string2) # '1.11'

string3 = "%.2f" % (1.117)
print(string3) # '1.12'
# %f is used to substitute floats within a string. Note, string1 includes extra zeroes. How about limiting 1.11
# to two decimal places? We can use %.2f
# If we pass a float that’s greater than two decimal places, then %.2f will round off the number.
1 + 2 = 3
1.110000
1.11
1.12
Show the code 
name = "sumendar"
greeting = "My name is {}".format(name)
greeting
'My name is sumendar'

print("happy" + " " + "birthday")
print("my name is " + "john")
happy birthday
my name is john

Escape Sequences in Strings

  • backslash () character is used in some strings to be treated one or more characters specially.
  • This is referred to as an escape sequence, because the backslash causes the subsequent character sequence to “escape” its usual meaning.
Show the code 
# print('This string contains a single quote (') character.')
# # gives a syntaxError
SyntaxError: invalid syntax (2279476380.py, line 1)
Show the code 
print('This string contains a single quote (\') character.')
print("This string contains a double quote (\") character.")
This string contains a single quote (') character.
This string contains a double quote (") character.
Show the code 
print("""a,
      b,
      c""")    # if we press Enter will gives SyntaxError after each letter
a,
      b,
      c
Show the code 
print('a\
b\
c')

print('a\
b\
c')
abc
abc
Show the code 
print('foo\\bar') # o include a literal backslash in a string, escape it with a backslash
foo\bar
Show the code 
print(r'foo\bar') # o include a literal backslash in a string, escape it with a letter r 
foo\bar

Applying Special Meaning to Characters

Show the code 
print('foo\tbar')
print("a\nb")
print('\u2192 \N{rightwards arrow}')
foo bar
a
b
→ →

Raw Strings

  • A raw string literal is preceded by r or R.
  • Escape sequences in the associated string are not translated. The backslash character is left in the string:
Show the code 
print('foo\nbar')
foo
bar
Show the code 
print(r'foo\nbar')
foo\nbar
Show the code 
print('foo\\bar')
foo\bar
Show the code 
print(r'foo\\bar')
foo\\bar

Triple-Quoted Strings

  • Escape sequences still work in triple-quoted strings, but single quotes, double quotes, and newlines can be included without escaping them.
  • This provides a convenient way to create a string with both single and double quotes in it:
Show the code 
print('''This string has a single (') and a double (") quote.''')
This string has a single (') and a double (") quote.
Show the code 
print("""This is a
string that spans
across several lines""")
# this also allows for multiline strings:
This is a
string that spans
across several lines

datetime module for date and time:

A date in Python is not a data type of its own, but we can import a module named datetime to work with dates as date objects.

strptime:

Show the code 
from datetime import datetime

time_data = "25/23/12 02:35:5.523"
print(type(time_data))
format_data = "%d/%y/%m %H:%M:%S.%f"
date = datetime.strptime(time_data, format_data)
print(date)
print(type(date))
<class 'str'>
2023-12-25 02:35:05.523000
<class 'datetime.datetime'>

time module:

Show the code 
#import time
import time
 
# get data of 4 th april 2021  at time 9 pm
print(time.strptime('30/12/21 09:31:22', '%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'))
 
# get data of 5 th april 2021  at time 9 pm
print(time.strptime('05/04/21 09:00:42', '%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'))
 
# get data of 6 th april 2021  at time 9 pm
print(time.strptime('06/04/21 09:11:42', '%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'))
 
# get data of 7 th april 2021  at time 9 pm
print(time.strptime('07/04/21 09:41:12', '%d/%m/%y %H:%M:%S'))
time.struct_time(tm_year=2021, tm_mon=12, tm_mday=30, tm_hour=9, tm_min=31, tm_sec=22, tm_wday=3, tm_yday=364, tm_isdst=-1)
time.struct_time(tm_year=2021, tm_mon=4, tm_mday=5, tm_hour=9, tm_min=0, tm_sec=42, tm_wday=0, tm_yday=95, tm_isdst=-1)
time.struct_time(tm_year=2021, tm_mon=4, tm_mday=6, tm_hour=9, tm_min=11, tm_sec=42, tm_wday=1, tm_yday=96, tm_isdst=-1)
time.struct_time(tm_year=2021, tm_mon=4, tm_mday=7, tm_hour=9, tm_min=41, tm_sec=12, tm_wday=2, tm_yday=97, tm_isdst=-1)
Show the code 
# import the datetime module
import datetime
 
# datetime in string format for may 25 1999
input = '2200/05/25'
 
# format
format = '%Y/%m/%d'
 
# convert from string format to datetime format
datetime = datetime.datetime.strptime(input, format)
print(type(datetime))
# get the date from the datetime using date()
# function
print(datetime.date())
<class 'datetime.datetime'>
2200-05-25
Show the code 
datetime.strftime('%A')
'Sunday'

Data Structures

(Non-primitive data structures)

Composite Data Types (Sequences)

Non-primitive types are the sophisticated members of the data structure family. They don’t just store a value, but rather a collection of values in various formats. * Lists are ordered sequences of values. * Tuples are ordered, sequences of values and immutable (cannot be modified inplace) * Dictionaries are unordered bags of key-value pairs. * Sets are unordered bags of values.

Lists

  • General purpose
  • Most widely used data structures
  • contain any type of objects or same type of obects and datatype
  • similar to arrays
  • can be extended or reduce the size as we needed
  • Sequence type
  • sortable
  • declare them using square brackets separated with commas of each value/item
  • Better to use this object for list of values which we need some flexibility to add/remove/sort/reverse/delete…etc operations.

Example: * List of employees in your department * List of stocks you want to analyze

Show the code 
mixed_data_types = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'grapes', 'mango', 12.89,True, 89, 'monday']
fruits1 = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry', 'grapes', 'mango']
Show the code 
print(type(mixed_data_types))
print(type(fruits1))
<class 'list'>
<class 'list'>
Show the code 
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits)

# Output: ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
Show the code 
fruit = ["apple", 45, True, 34.56]
print(fruit)

# Output: ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
['apple', 45, True, 34.56]
Show the code 
A = [] # This is a blank list variable
ages = [19, 23, 45, 67] # this list creates an initial list of 4 numbers.
C = [2, 4, 'john'] # lists can contain different variable types.

list

The + operator concatenates lists:

Show the code 
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [4, 5, 6]
c = a + b  # 
print(c)
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

Similarly, the * operator repeats a list a given number of times:

Show the code 
 
[0,1] * 4
[0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 1]
Show the code 
[1, 2, 3] * 3  # The first example repeats [0] four times. The second example repeats the list [1, 2, 3] three times.
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3]

The Difference Between “is” and “==” in Python

Show the code 
a = 'banana'
b = 'banana'
a is b
True
Show the code 
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]
a is b
False

What does [::-1} do?

Show the code 
l = [1,2,3,4,5]
print(l[::-1]) # reverse the order of list as list of values, original list order not changing
print(l)
[5, 4, 3, 2, 1]
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
Show the code 
l1 = [1,2,3,4,5]
l1.reverse() # original object inplace changed values order
print(l1)     
[5, 4, 3, 2, 1]

follow along: https://dbader.org/blog/difference-between-is-and-equals-in-python
https://medium.com/@tyastropheus/tricky-python-i-memory-management-for-mutable-immutable-objects-21507d1e5b95

Built-in Functions with List

Function Description
any() Return True if any element of the list is true. If the list is empty, return False.
all() Returns True if all elements of an iterable are true
len() Return the length (the number of items) in the list.
list() Convert an iterable (tuple, string, set, dictionary) to a list.
max() Return the largest item in the list.
min() Return the smallest item in the list
sorted() Return a new sorted list (does not sort the list itself).
reversed() Returns a reverse iterator
sum() Return the sum of all elements in the list.

Python list Methods

Methods Functions
append() to add element to the end of the list
extend() to extend all elements of a list to the another list
insert() to insert an element at the another index
remove() to remove an element from the list
pop() to remove elements return element at the given index
clear() to remove all elements from the list
index() to return the index of the first matched element
count() to count of number of elements passed as an argument
sort() to sort the elements in ascending order by default
reverse() to reverse order element in a list
copy() to return a copy of elements in a list

copy() method vs direct assignment

Show the code 
l1 = [1,2,3,4]
l2 = l1
print(id(l1))
print(id(l2))
2229711329088
2229711329088
Show the code 
l1.append(999)
print(l2)
[1, 2, 3, 4, 999]
Show the code 
l1 = [1,2,3,4]
l2 = l1.copy()
print(id(l1))
print(id(l2))
2229711330624
2229711330880
Show the code 
l1.append(999)
print(l2)
[1, 2, 3, 4]

http://thepythonguru.com/python-lists/
https://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/python_lists.htm

Tuples

  • Immutable (we cannot change its content inplace after creation)
  • Better for fixed data
  • useful to share the data with someone but not allow them to manipulate
  • use the data values for arithmatic operations, however the changes is not reflected in the original data
  • contain any type of objects (heterogeneous container for items)
  • similar to arrays
  • faster compare with the lists
  • sequencey type
  • To declare tuples we use parentheses.
  • Unlike Python lists, tuples does not have methods such as append(), remove(), extend(), insert() and pop() due to its immutable nature. However, there are many other built-in methods to work with tuple
  • Better to use this object for a list of values which order really matters when there is no need to add/delete those items

Example: * List of months, or weekdays..etc * List of top 10 sales regions in a quarter

Show the code 
fruits = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")
print(fruits)

# Output: ('apple', 'banana', 'cherry')
('apple', 'banana', 'cherry')
Show the code 
l = [3,6,1,9,0]
type(l)
list
Show the code 
l[0] = 999
Show the code 
l
[999, 6, 1, 9, 0]
Show the code 
t = (-61,32,99,45)
Show the code 
type(t)
tuple

tuple=("yasir","basit","nemath") # primary

Composite Data Types (Mappings)

Dictionaries (key-value pair)

  • Each item is a pair of a key and value
  • It holds word-meaning pairs just like real dictionaries
  • Un ordered
  • Dictionaries are not sorted
  • Access to the list of keys or values independently.
  • To create / declare a dictionary, we use curly braces.
  • Better to use this object for unordered storage of values which are associated with some keys

Examples: * Employee name associated with Employee ID
* Aadhar no associated with indian citizen * Order status of online food

Show the code 
person = {"name": "John", "age": 30, "city": "New York"}
print(person)

# Output: {'name': 'John', 'age': 30, 'city': 'New York'} (Note: the order may vary)
{'name': 'John', 'age': 30, 'city': 'New York'}
Show the code 
room_num = {'john': 425, 'tom': 212} # key value combination

Sets (set theory kind of mapping)

  • Sets are useful when you have a collection of elements that need to be unique and unordered.
  • Python set is much like a mathematical set theory in that it has well-defined collection of distinct objects
  • The objects of a set are called its “elements”.
  • Sets are unordered collections of unique elements. Duplicates are not allowed.
  • very fast access vs lists
  • A set itself may be modified, but the elements contained in the set must be of an immutable type (eg. it might be a tuple but not a list type).
  • Python provides us with a list of methods like discard(), pop(), clear(), remove(), add(), and more. Functions like len() and max() also apply on sets.
  • It is sequenced (automatically while printing), but does not support indexing.
  • To declare a set, write a sequence of items separated with commas, inside curly braces.
  • Better to use this object a collection of sets which needs to membership or mapping really matters
Show the code 
s = {1,2,3}
Show the code 
type(s)
set

Adding Elements to a Set
* sets are mutable – but since they are unordered, indexes would not make any sense to it. We will not be able to access or update an element based on the index of an element in a set, as set does not support both indexing and slicing.
* we can use the add() method to add a single element if we need to add more than one element to a set, we can use the update() method

Show the code 
# creating a set
a = {1, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13} # direct with square bracket individual values
b = set([1, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13]) # we have included a list and req set function to make a new set

Set Operations on Sets

  • Union
  • Intersection
  • Difference
  • Symmetric Difference

Show the code 
fruits ={"Bananas","Apples","Grapes","Strawberries","Oranges","Watermelons","Tomatoes", "Pumpkins", "Cucumbers","String beans","Eggplant"}
vegitables = {"Tomatoes", "Pumpkins", "Cucumbers","String beans","Eggplant","onion", "green pepper", "cabbage", "cauliflower"}
print ( vegitables & fruits )
print ( vegitables.intersection(fruits) )
{'Eggplant', 'String beans', 'Pumpkins', 'Tomatoes', 'Cucumbers'}
{'Eggplant', 'String beans', 'Pumpkins', 'Tomatoes', 'Cucumbers'}
Show the code 
# Intersection
A = {1, 2, 3, 4}
B = {3, 4, 5, 6}
print ( A & B )
print ( A.intersection(B) )
{3, 4}
{3, 4}
Show the code 
# Union
A = {1, 2, 3, 4} # set A
B = {3, 4, 5, 6} # set B
print ( A | B)    # AUB with pipe symbol
print(A.union(B))  # method
{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}
{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}
Show the code 
# Difference
A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
B = {4, 5, 6, 7, 8}
print(A - B) #its not a subtraction
print(A.difference(B))
{1, 2, 3}
{1, 2, 3}
Show the code 
# Symmetric Difference
A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
B = {4, 5, 6, 7, 8}
print(A ^ B)
{1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8}

Remove Elements From a Set

discard()
This method takes the item to delete as an argument. * deleting an item that doesn’t exist in the set, discard() ignores it

Show the code 
num = {13,12,21,43,16,25}
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43}
Show the code 
# num[3]
TypeError: 'set' object is not subscriptable
Show the code 
num.discard(3)
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43}

remove()

Like the discard() method, remove() deletes an item from the set. * deleting an item that doesn’t exist in the set, remove() gives an error

Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43}
Show the code 
# num.remove(5)
KeyError: 5
Show the code 
num.discard(16)
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 21, 25, 43}
Show the code 
num.remove(43)
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 21, 25}

pop() * here, it does not take an argument. Because a set doesn’t support indexing * it pops out an arbitrary item. * we will not be able to determine which element of the set will be removed using the pop() method. In case of list, the last element of the list gets popped when the pop() method is used.

Show the code 
num = {13,12,21,43,16,25}
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43}
Show the code 
num.pop()
43
Show the code 
num
{12, 13}

We can also remove all items from a set using clear().

clear() * It empties the set in Python.

Show the code 
num = {13,12,21,43,16,25}
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43}
Show the code 
num.clear()
Show the code 
num
set()
Show the code 
num = {13,12,21,43,16,25}
Show the code 
num.add(84)
Show the code 
num
{12, 13, 16, 21, 25, 43, 84}

Stacks(LIFO)

""" A Stack of Bills to Pay """
# python doesn't has built-n stack module, we can use list instead
# create a list to use as the stack
stack = list()
Show the code 
# add some bills to the stack
stack.append('bill1')
stack.append('bill2') # lat entered
Show the code 
# remove the top bill to pay it#  
print(stack.pop()) # the last entered comes out first
bill2
Show the code 
print(stack.pop()) # last before will comes out
bill1
Show the code 
# add two more bills to the stack
stack.append('bill3')
stack.append('bill4')

# remove bills from top to bottom
print(stack.pop())
print(stack.pop())
# print(stack.pop())
# stack.pop() 
bill4
bill3

Queues(FIFO)

Show the code 
""" A Queue of Groceries to Put Away """
# queue is a not built-in datatype
# create a new queue object
import queue 
q = queue.Queue() # create a new object by calling new Queue() custroctor
print(q.empty()) # its showing True bcz its an empty queue
True
Show the code 
# put bags into the queue
q.put('bag1')
print(q.empty())
q.put('bag2')
q.put('bag3')
False
Show the code 
# get bags from the queue in FIFO order
print(q.get())
print(q.get())
print(q.get())
# q.get() # causes an error: blocking method, the program will wait until method completes before continuiing execution
# (restart the shell) 
bag1
bag2
bag3
Show the code 
# create a new queue to hold two items
q = queue.Queue(2) # here we are limiting two two elements/items
print(q.empty())

# put two bags into the two-item queue
q.put('bag1')
print(q.full())
q.put('bag2')
print(q.full())
True
False
True

Implicit type conversion

Show the code 
int1 = 4
float1 = int1 + 2.1 # 4 converted to float
print(float1)
# str1 = "new" + int1 # Error: no implicit type conversion from int to string
int2 = 4 + True # 5: bool is implicitly converted to int
print(int2)
6.1
5

Explicit type conversion

Show the code 
int(2.7) # converting float value to integer value 
2
Show the code 
str1 = "new_str" + str(int1)
print(str1) # new_str4
new_str4
Show the code 
v1 = int(2.7) # 2
v2 = int(-3.9) # -3
v3 = int("2") # 2
v4 = int("11", 16) # 17, base 16
v6 = float(2) # 2.0
v7 = float("2.7") # 2.7
v8 = float("2.7E-2") # 0.027
v9 = float(False) # 0.0
vA = float(True) # 1.0
vB = str(4.5) # "4.5"
vC = str([1, 3, 5]) # "[1, 3, 5]"
vD = bool(0) # False; bool fn since Python 2.2.1
vE = bool(3) # True
vF = bool([]) # False - empty list
vG = bool([False]) # True - non-empty list
vH = bool({}) # False - empty dict; same for empty tuple
vI = bool("") # False - empty string
vJ = bool(" ") # True - non-empty string
vK = bool(None) # False
vL = bool(len) # True
vM = set([1, 2])
vN = list(vM)
vO = list({1: "a", 2: "b"}) # dict -> list of keys
# vP = tuple(vN)
vQ = list("abc") # ['a', 'b', 'c']
# print v1, v2, v3, type(v1), type(v2), type(v3)

#
# Read and write files using the built-in Python file methods
#
#def main():  
  # Open a file for writing and create it if it doesn't exist
f = open("data/textfile.txt","w+")
  
  # Open the file for appending text to the end
  # f = open("textfile.txt","a+")

  # write some lines of data to the file
for i in range(11):
    f.write("This is line %d\r\n" % (i+1))
  
      # close the file when done
f.close()
Show the code 
  # Open the file back up and read the contents
f = open("data/textfile.txt","r")
if f.mode == 'r': # check to make sure that the file was opened
    # use the read() function to read the entire file
    contents = f.read()
    print (contents)
    
# fl = f.readlines() # readlines reads the individual lines into a list
# for x in fl:
#       print (x)
    
# w --> write
# r --> read
# r+ --> read and write
# a --> append

Getting Help in Spyder IDE/Jupyter Notebook

Shortcuts:

Place the cursor at the beginning/end/betwwen and press ctrl+i to know the syntax, type, description and examples with in spyder or either use single ? or double ‘??’ before or after a function the help document in the console

Place the cursor at the betwwen/end and press Shift+Tab to know the syntax, object type, description with in Jupyter

Show the code 
print("hello")
hello

Write help() function for the function we need then we get help of the function in the above help pane for the spyder and below the cell of the jupyter

Show the code 
help(print)
Help on built-in function print in module builtins:

print(...)
    print(value, ..., sep=' ', end='\n', file=sys.stdout, flush=False)
    
    Prints the values to a stream, or to sys.stdout by default.
    Optional keyword arguments:
    file:  a file-like object (stream); defaults to the current sys.stdout.
    sep:   string inserted between values, default a space.
    end:   string appended after the last value, default a newline.
    flush: whether to forcibly flush the stream.

Write single question mark ?before/after of the function to get the help of the function to display below the script for the spyder and seperate pane for the jupyter

Help on function mean in module statistics:

mean(data)
    Return the sample arithmetic mean of data.
    
    >>> mean([1, 2, 3, 4, 4])
    2.8
    
    >>> from fractions import Fraction as F
    >>> mean([F(3, 7), F(1, 21), F(5, 3), F(1, 3)])
    Fraction(13, 21)
    
    >>> from decimal import Decimal as D
    >>> mean([D("0.5"), D("0.75"), D("0.625"), D("0.375")])
    Decimal('0.5625')
    
    If ``data`` is empty, StatisticsError will be raised.
